title-group.article-title: Attachment, Activity Limitation, and Health Symptoms in Later Life
title-group.subtitle: The Mediating Roles of Negative (and Positive) Affect

article-meta.aff: 2Gordon F. Derner Institute of Advanced Psychological Studies, Adelphi University, Garden City, USA
3Netherlands Interdisciplinary Demographic Institute, The Hague, Netherlands

author-notes.corresp: Nathan S. Consedine, PhD, Department of Psychological Medicine,The University of Auckland, Level 12, Support Building, Room 12.003, Private Bag 92019, Auckland, NewZealand Email: n.consedine@auckland.ac.nz

abstract.p: Objectives: Patterns of attachment—normative styles of relating to significant others—impact relationships across adulthood. Preliminary studies link attachment with health outcomes but have yet to examine older adults or functional impairment, and the mechanisms behind this relationship remain unclear. This report investigated how attachment predicted symptoms and functional impairment and tested the mediating roles of positive affect (PA) and negative affect (NA). Methods: 1,118 older adults completed measures of attachment, health symptoms, and functional impairment, together with confounds including age, sex, and income. Results: As expected, security and fearful avoidance predicted greater symptomology, but only fearful avoidance predicted greater functional impairment. Negative affect partially mediated links between attachment and outcomes, but only for fearful avoidance. Discussion: Understanding links between attachment, symptom reports, and functional impairment will facilitate better understanding of positive aging versus premature decline, help identify at risk individuals, and guide interventions to assist optimal functioning in later life.

body.p: Attachment theory suggests that early interactions with caregivers impact how individuals relate to significant others throughout their lives (Bowlby, 1969). Harsh, inconsistent, or nonresponsive caregiving results in compensatory, insecure styles, whereas security results where early needs are consistently met (Bowlby, 1969). As the individual develops, repeated experiences are internalized in an attachment “style,” a complex system of representations, expectancies, and beliefs about the self and others (Ainsworth, 1989; Bowlby, 1980; Cicirelli, 2004; Collins & Read, 1994; Mickelson, Kessler, & Shaver, 1997; Montague, Magai, Consedine, & Gillespie, 2003) that comes to guide how people relate to others across the lifespan. Although predominantly studied among younger adults, attachment appears particularly significant when facing challenging situations (Magai & Consedine, 2004), including threat, increases in dependency, interpersonal losses, or illness, and may thus be of considerable relevance to later life health and adaptation.

Preliminary evidence has linked attachment—a dispositional style of relating to others—with health outcomes, such as medically unexplained symptoms (Ciechanowski, Katon, Russo, & Dwight-Johnson, 2002), and health care utilization (Ciechanowski, Walker, Katon, & Russo, 2002; Feeney & Ryan, 1994). Research has examined how attachment styles relate to symptom reporting, with data indicating that anxious styles such as ambivalent (Feeney & Ryan, 1994) and fearful avoidant (Wearden, Lamberton, Crook, & Walsh, 2005) predict greater reported symptoms. Given that a large portion of health care utilization occurs in response to subjective symptom reports, understanding the mechanisms linking attachment to symptom reporting is increasingly important.

One possible pathway linking attachment to health lies in the tendency for persons with different attachment profiles to differentially experience and regulate aspects of positive and negative emotionality (Consedine, Fiori, & Magai, 2012; Consedine & Magai, 2003). The global positivity and/or negativity of emotion experience are often subsumed within the terms positive affect and negative “affect,” (PA and NA, respectively) two general and enduring dimensions of subjective (emotional) experience (Watson & Clark, 1984). It is generally accepted that positive states are not the opposite of negative states (Russell & Carroll, 1999). The two are only weakly correlated, with variations in PA and NA being largely independent (Watson & Clark, 1984). More important, in terms of health, NA is a robust predictor of symptom reporting (Consedine & Moskowitz, 2007), possibly because individuals high in NA are more self-vigilant and attentive and thus more likely to notice symptoms or interpret them as threatening (Watson & Pennebaker, 1989).

As noted, reports of affectivity are closely linked to attachment (Consedine et al., 2012). Persons with greater attachment security report greater PA, but less NA (Consedine & Fiori, 2009), whereas fearful, anxious, or preoccupied styles generally predict greater NA (Consedine & Fiori, 2009). Dismissive/avoidant attachment is more complex, generally predicting reduced reports of sadness and anxiety (Consedine & Magai, 2003) but greater hostility/defensiveness, disgust, and contempt (Mikulincer & Florian, 1998). Taken together, these findings suggest that NA may mediate links between attachment and symptom reporting, and this has been evidenced among both university students (Feeney & Ryan, 1994; Wearden, Cook, & Vaughan-Jones, 2003; Wearden et al., 2005) and in a single nonstudent sample aged 15 to 67 years (M = 36.77, SD = 11.69) from the North of England (Armitage & Harris, 2006).

However, although these studies represent an important beginning to understanding attachment–health links, several issues remain unexplored. To date, most studies examining whether NA mediates attachment–health links have used student samples (Feeney & Ryan, 1994; Wearden et al., 2005). Few studies have investigated older adults in the context of attachment and health, despite at least two pressing reasons for their examination. First, health is a less salient consideration for younger cohorts, meaning the relevance of attachment characteristics may be exaggerated or distorted in student samples. Second, there are consistent differences in patterns of attachment across age cohorts, with more dismissive and fewer preoccupied and fearful-avoidant classifications in older groups (Consedine & Magai, 2003; Fiori, Consedine, & Magai, 2009). Whether attachment predicts health outcomes in older samples and the possible mediating role of NA is yet to be examined.

Second, although the role of NA has been explored, research at the attachment–health interface is yet to examine the possible role of PA in attachment–health links. Data suggest that PA predicts better health outcomes (see review in Pressman & Cohen, 2005), including reduced susceptibility to viral infection, less severe symptomology (Cohen, Doyle, Turner, Alper, & Skoner, 2003), and lower mortality risk (Moskowitz, Epel, & Acree, 2008), even when controlling for NA. Consequently, low PA rather than high NA, may be the driving force behind attachment-related differences in symptom reports. Persons with greater security report more PA (Mikulincer & Florian, 1998), as do those high in avoidance or dismissiveness (Consedine & Magai, 2003). Conversely, PA is lower among anxious or preoccupied types (Consedine & Magai, 2003). As attachment is a robust predictor of PA, it is possible that PA may also contribute to the mediation of attachment–health links.

Finally, most attachment–health research has concentrated on explaining links between attachment and symptom reports. However, “health” is more than the absence of symptoms, particularly for aging adults. Typical signs of aging, such as functional impairment, normatively increase with age, threaten autonomy (Baltes, 1996), and may be linked to patterns of attachment. Individuals with different attachment characteristics may under- or over-report functional impairment, depending on their attachment-related motivations.

Although data are yet to link attachment with functional impairment, recent theoretical work suggests that attachment has implications for how individuals adapt to the dependencies of aging (Merz & Consedine, 2009). Individuals with different attachment profiles hold different values regarding loss, dependency, and the aging process (Alonso-Arbiol, Shaver, & Yarnoz, 2002; Fiori, Consedine, & Magai, 2008). Security is associated with the ability to mobilize support networks when needed and more effective engagement with the medical establishment (Maunder & Hunter, 2009). Such a pattern suggests functional impairments should be lower among secure styles. Conversely, dismissiveness is associated with stoicism, a preference for self-reliance, and a tendency to downplay dependency or need (Merz & Consedine, 2009). Consequently, we might expect fewer reported functional impairments among these persons. Finally, given that persons with fearful or anxious styles characteristically hyperactivate the attachment system and continually signal need to the social environment, we should expect greater functional impairment as a result of this characteristic.

sec.title: Hypotheses and the Current Study
sec.p: Based on the extant data together with insights drawn from theories of attachment and the emotions–health literature, we expected that fearful avoidance would predict reports of greater symptoms and functional impairment. We predicted that attachment security would be associated with greater reported symptoms, but less functional impairment, and dismissiveness would predict fewer health symptoms and less functional impairment. Consistent with prior work, we expected NA to be positively associated with reported symptoms and/or functional impairment but greater PA to be negatively associated with these two outcomes. Finally, we expected mediation to occur, with NA being the more likely meditational candidate.

sec.title: Participants
sec.p: The data were drawn from a cross-sectional population-based study of stress and coping in older Americans, the Brooklyn Older Adults Study (BOAS), conducted from 1996 to 1999. A community-dwelling sample of 1,118 people aged 65+ years (65-86 years) stratified by race (Black/White) and income was compiled using a cluster technique. Census block data were extracted from the “Household Income and Race Summary” tape of the 1990 U.S. population census. Random selection without replacement was used to choose samples of block groups from each stratum.

Because of the parent study’s focus on representing the diverse communities of Brooklyn, New York, recruitment differentiated between U.S.-born African Americans and immigrant African (Black) Caribbeans from islands in the West Indies, and the European American sample was broken down into U.S.-born European Americans and European (White) immigrants. For the current report, we describe the sample using the terms “Black” for the two African-descent groups (U.S.-born African Americans and Immigrant Black Caribbeans) and “White” for the U.S.-born European American and immigrant European samples. Immigrant and nonimmigrant respondents in the selected blocks were interviewed and paid US$20 for their participation. Trained, race-matched interviewers conducted interviews lasting approximately one-and-a-half hours, in the respondent’s home or at another location of their choice (e.g., a senior center or church). Demographic and sample information can be found in Table 1.

sec.title: Health Risks Questionnaire
sec.p: Participants recorded smoking and drinking history, as well as height and weight, which were combined to calculate body mass index (BMI; kg/m2). The Frequency-Quantity Index (Knupper, Fink, Clark, & Goffman, 1963) asks respondents to indicate their frequency of drinking beer, wine, and spirits to create an aggregate drinking measure (α = .73). Respondents also indicated the number and/or packs of cigarettes they smoked daily and the number of years they smoked. Both drinking and smoking variables were skewed and did not respond to transformations, and so were dichotomized on a present/absent basis.

sec.title: Self-reported health symptomology
sec.p: Physical health was assessed using the physical health scales of the Comprehensive Assessment and Referral Evaluation (CARE; Golden, Teresi, & Gurland, 1984). The CARE is a semistructured instrument developed to assess health among community-dwelling older adults. It has good construct, concurrent, and predictive validity (Teresi, Golden, & Gurland, 1984; Teresi, Golden, Gurland, Wilder, & Bennett, 1984). For the current study, 119 items from the somatic symptoms, heart disorder, stroke, respiratory symptoms, arthritis, leg problems, sleep disorder, hearing disorder, vision disorder, and hypertension scales were combined to form an aggregate health symptoms scale (α = .94). Questions are answered in a yes/no format. Items include questions such as, “Are you taking a drug prescribed for hypertension?,” “Do you have pain in your joints?,” and so on. Participants had a mean number of symptoms close to 18 (SD = 14.4; see Table 1).

sec.title: Functional impairment
sec.p: The 39-item Disabilities subscale from the Core CARE was used to index impairment in the ability to perform activities of daily living (α = .96). Questions describe impairment due to health issues, are answered in a yes/no format, and include items such as, “Do you have difficulty dressing by yourself?” and “Do your health troubles limit social activities?” Participants averaged 5.39 impairments (SD = 8.31; see Table 1). Given that both symptomology and functional impairment scores were skewed, square root transformations were performed prior to analysis.

sec.title: Attachment
sec.p: The 30-item Relationship Scales Questionnaire (RSQ; Griffin & Bartholomew, 1994) measured four styles of attachment (secure, fearful avoidant, dismissing, and preoccupied). Respondents rate how well each item describes their characteristic style in close relationships using 5-point scales. Because the internal consistency of the four subscales was unacceptably low in the present sample, we conducted principal components analysis with Varimax rotation to verify the underlying data structure. This revealed a three-factor solution discriminating three attachment types. The first two map onto the secure and dismissing components of Hazan and Shaver’s (1987) original measure, whereas the item loadings suggested that the third component was better described as fearful avoidance (Bartholomew & Horowitz, 1991) than preoccupation. In the present data, the Secure subscale consisted of RSQ Items 3, 4, 8, 14, and 30; the Dismissing subscale consisted of RSQ Items 1, 2, 19, 22, 26; and the Fearful Avoidant subscale consisted of RSQ Items 5, 7, 11, 12, 13, 16, 17, 20, 21, 23, 24, 25, and 29. The alpha coefficients for these three subscales were .77, .61, and .79, respectively.

sec.title: Trait emotionality
sec.p: Trait positive and negative emotionality were measured by the trait version of the Differential Emotions Scale, Version-III (DES-III; Izard, 1972). This 30-item scale was developed for use with individuals who may have limited education. There are 3 items for each of 10 fundamental emotions: joy, surprise, interest, fear, sadness, anger, contempt, disgust, shame, and guilt. Respondents rate, on a scale of 1 to 5, how much each emotion characterizes their day-to-day experience. The scale has been used in numerous investigations on emotion and enjoys strong psychometric properties (Izard, 1972). The alpha coefficients for all scales are .84 or greater. The average 1-week test–retest reliability for the scales is .77. In the present study the alpha coefficient of reliability for the Negative Affect subscale (consisting of the mean ratings for sadness, anger, shame, contempt, guilt, disgust, and fear) was .90. However, because the distribution was skewed, a log transformation was performed. This transformation improved normality (from skewness = .641, to skewness = –.033, SE = 0.073), and therefore we used the log-transformed version of the Negative Affect subscale in our final analyses. The Positive Affect subscale (consisting of the mean ratings for two positive emotions, joy and interest) had an alpha coefficient of .69. “Surprise” was not included in the derivation due to lack of a defined valence (Fiori et al., 2008). The skewness and kurtosis of the Positive Affect subscale were acceptable (skewness = –.341, SE = 0.073; kurtosis = .044, SE = 0.146), and transformations did not improve normality. Therefore, the nontransformed version of this variable was used in the final analyses. NA and PA were used as mediators in the present study.

sec.title: Analytic Strategy
sec.p: To examine our predictions regarding links between attachment dimensions and the two health outcomes as well as the possible mediating roles of NA and PA, a series of hierarchical regressions were performed. In these analyses, we controlled for sex, age, education, marital status, income, race, BMI, and health behaviors. Tests of mediation were based on established definitions stating that complete mediation occurs only when the effect of the independent variable (IV) on the dependent variable (DV) is reduced to zero when controlling for the mediator (Baron & Kenny, 1986). To test for the significance of partial mediation, we calculated the percentage of total effect mediated according to the formula: αβ / (αβ + τ1), where α represents the coefficient relating the IV to the mediator, β represents the coefficient relating the mediator to the outcome adjusted for the IV, and τ1 represents the coefficient relating the IV to the outcome adjusted for the mediator (Sobel, 1982). The product αβ represents the mediated or indirect effect, and τ1 represents the nonmediated or direct effect. We report the percentage of the total effect that is mediated in order to facilitate comparisons across regressions.

sec.title: Descriptive Analyses
sec.p: Descriptive statistics for the sample can be found in Table 1, and bivariate correlations among all study variables can be found in Table 2. Women reported greater dismissive attachment, PA, NA, symptoms, and functional impairment than men. Older adults reported more symptoms and functional impairment. More highly educated individuals reported greater secure attachment, dismissive attachment, PA, and health symptoms. Married individuals rated themselves as more secure and less fearful avoidant and dismissive with less functional impairment. Individuals with greater income were less fearful avoidant, had lower NA, and reported fewer symptoms and less functional impairment. Black adults reported greater secure and fearful avoidant attachment, greater NA and PA, greater symptoms, and more functional impairment. Although BMI was positively associated with symptoms and functional impairment, the “drinking” variable was negatively associated with functional impairment. Finally, note that all three attachment styles were positively correlated with both reports of symptoms and functional impairment and that PA was positively correlated and NA negatively correlated with both outcome variables.

sec.title: Associations Between Attachment Components and Affect
sec.p: Table 3 shows the associations between attachment styles and measures of trait affect. Secure attachment was positively associated with both NA and PA, whereas fearful avoidant attachment was only positively associated with NA and to a greater extent than secure attachment (β = .41 compared to .07). Dismissive attachment was positively correlated with PA, and there was a trend such that it was negatively correlated with NA (β = –.05).

caption.p: Two Hierarchical Multiple Linear Regressions Predicting (a) Negative and (b) Positive Affect From Attachment Dimensions

fn.p: Note: Steps 1 and 2 for positive affect regression are not shown since they are identical to the negative affect regression.

sec.title: Multivariate Predictors of Health Outcome
sec.p: Table 4 shows the two hierarchical linear regressions for the health symptom outcome (one regression for NA, the other for PA). As can be seen in Step 2, only secure and fearful avoidant attachment were significantly (positively) associated with health symptoms. The addition of NA in Step 3 reduced the beta for fearful avoidance to the level of a trend. We explain this mediation effect in terms of Baron and Kenny’s (1986) definition of mediation. We first established that there was a significant relationship between fearful avoidant attachment and symptoms (B = 0.41, SE = 0.07, p < .001; Table 4); then, variations in levels of fearful avoidant attachment significantly accounted for variations in NA (B = 0.08, SE = 0.01, p < .001; Table 3), and variations in NA (the mediator) significantly accounted for variations in symptoms while controlling for attachment (B = 3.30, SE = 0.42, p < .001; Table 4); finally, when the path between NA and health symptoms was controlled, the relationship between fearful avoidant attachment and symptoms was diminished (from B = 0.41, SE = 0.07, to B = 0.15, SE = 0.08).

caption.p: Two Hierarchical Multiple Linear Regressions Predicting Total Health Symptoms From Attachment Dimensions and (a) Negative Affect and (b) Positive Affect

fn.p: Note: Other than attachment variables, only significant coefficients are shown. Step 1 variables entered included education, marital status, drinking and smoking history (not shown). Steps 1 and 2 for positive affect regression are identical to negative affect and are not shown.

sec.p: This decrease was significant according to the Sobel test statistic (z = 7.05, p < .001), confirming partial mediation. Furthermore, 64% of the effect of fearful avoidant attachment on health symptoms was mediated by NA. As can also be seen in Table 4, PA did not reduce the effects of either secure or fearful avoidant attachment on health symptoms, so mediation was not tested.

Table 5 shows the two hierarchical linear regressions for the functional impairment outcome (one regression for NA, the other for PA). As can be seen in Step 2, greater fearful avoidance significantly predicted functional impairment. Although the addition of PA did not reduce this effect, the addition of NA reduced the beta for fearful avoidance to nonsignificance. Specifically, when the path between NA and functional impairment was controlled, the relationship between fearful avoidance and functional impairment diminished (from B = 0.23, SE = 0.07, to B = 0.07, SE = 0.08). This decrease was significant according to the Sobel test (z = 4.57, p < .001), confirming partial mediation. Furthermore, 70% of the effect of fearful avoidant attachment on functional impairment was mediated by NA.

caption.p: Two Hierarchical Multiple Linear Regressions Predicting Functional Impairment From Attachment Dimensions and (a) Negative and (b) Positive Affect

fn.p: Note: Other than attachment variables, only significant coefficients are shown. Step1 variables entered included education, marital status, and smoking history (not shown). Steps 1 and 2 for positive affect regression are identical to negative affect and are not shown.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: Given increases in life expectancy, understanding the psychosocial factors associated with symptom reporting and functional impairment among older adults is of growing concern. Established links between attachment and values regarding loss, disability, and dependency (Alonso-Arbiol et al., 2002; Merz & Consedine, 2009) suggest that attachment theory may have implications for how individuals adapt to the challenges of ageing. This report investigated links between attachment, symptom reports, and functional impairment in a large (N = 1,118), geographically representative sample of community-dwelling men and women aged 65+ years.

Consistent with expectation, we found that although both security and fearful avoidance predicted greater symptom reporting, only fearful avoidance was associated with greater functional impairment. Contrary to expectation, we found no relationship between dismissive attachment and functional impairment or symptom reports. As expected, greater NA was independently associated with worse outcomes, and greater PA predicted better outcomes. As importantly, our analyses provided preliminary evidence that PA and NA may mediate some attachment–outcome links. Specifically, although NA appeared to mediate the links between fearful avoidance and health outcomes, it did not mediate the relationships between attachment security and outcomes. Finally, controlling for PA uncovered a positive relationship between secure attachment and functional impairment.

sec.title: Fearful Avoidance
sec.p: Given prior work linking fearful avoidance with poorer health (Ciechanowski, Walker et al., 2002; Kidd & Sheffield, 2005), it was not surprising that fearful avoidance was the most consistent predictor of both symptomology and functional impairment. High NA is characteristic of fearful avoidance (Bartholomew, 1993; Ciechanowski, Sullivan, Jensen, Romano, & Summers, 2003) and appears to play a role. NA predicts greater reported symptoms (Watson & Pennebaker, 1989), and though a direct link is possible (Consedine & Moskowitz, 2007), it is likely that the self-attentional focus characterizing NA is central. Depressed affect in particular is associated with an internal focus that heightens symptom awareness and increases the odds that symptoms are interpreted negatively (Pennebaker, 2000). Consistent with this view, fearful avoidance predicts catastrophizing about symptoms (Ciechanowski et al., 2003) and hypochondriasis (Noyes et al., 2003), although it has also been suggested that individuals high in fearful avoidance may have poorer health due to sustained differences in physiological threat response systems (Gouin et al., 2009).

Not surprisingly, given greater reported symptomology, persons high in fearful avoidance also report greater functional impairment. Characteristically, individuals high in fearful avoidance desire support but fear rejection and may avoid seeking help (Bowlby, 1973). Previous research suggests that although fearfully avoidant individuals report the most symptoms, they also have the lowest primary care costs and utilization (Ciechanowski, Walker et al., 2002). Although the direction of the relationships among utilization, symptomology, and impairment remains unclear, it is possible that low utilization contributes to worse health outcomes or that impairments interfere with utilization and thus lead to a worsening of chronic health issues. A final possibility is that individuals high in fearful avoidance may reduce independent functioning and increase symptom reports as a nonconscious means of “managing” their support network. Specifically, accessing care and attention through functional disability may allow persons high in fearful avoidance to disguise their characteristic need for emotional proximity by framing it as a functional need for physical assistance, thus reducing the risk of rejection.

sec.title: Security
sec.p: As expected, security also predicted greater symptom reports. Although prior work has found secure styles report fewer symptoms than preoccupied, they typically report more symptoms than either dismissing and fearfully avoidant individuals (Ciechanowski, Walker et al., 2002). Although the absence of a preoccupied dimension should be borne in mind, our initial interpretation is that this positive link reflects accurate symptom reporting rather than overreporting. Secure persons have more accurate illness perceptions (Bazzazian & Besharat, 2012) and more effectively collaborate in clinical settings (Maunder & Hunter, 2009). Security is associated with the ability to acknowledge distress and with more effective coping and support seeking (Bartholomew & Horowitz, 1991).

More importantly, despite predicting greater symptomology, security was not related to functional impairment. This may suggest greater adaptation or resilience (Magai, Consedine, King, & Gillespie, 2003) in the face of illness. The psychological profile of more secure individuals may enable them to acknowledge (rather than deny) symptomology, whereas comfort with help seeking and medical consults may facilitate symptom management. More effective engagement with the medical establishment (Maunder & Hunter, 2009) should lead to earlier and more accurate diagnoses, and more accurate illness perceptions (Bazzazian & Besharat, 2012) may lead to increased adherence to symptom/disease management recommendations.

sec.title: Dismissiveness
sec.p: Although the effects associated with fearful avoidance and security were consistent with our expectations, effects regarding dismissiveness were not. Data revealed no links between dismissiveness and either symptom reporting or functional impairment. Our expectations were based on the notion that core dismissive characteristics such as self-reliance (Bartholomew & Horowitz, 1991), low self-reported NA (Bartholomew & Horowitz, 1991; Consedine & Fiori, 2009), and repressive coping (Consedine et al., 2012) might lead to a downplaying of symptoms and avoidance of help seeking. For example, repressors have been shown to ignore pain and fatigue (Temoshok, 2000) and more defended/low-affect personality types report better subjective health (Brosschot & Janssen, 1998).

Conversely, dismissive types typically have worse objective health outcomes. Defensiveness, alone or as part of the repressive personality, has been linked to impaired immune functioning (Jamner & Leigh, 1999), whereas repression predicts poorer health outcomes in several areas (Denollet, Martens, Nyklicek, Conraads, & de Gelder, 2008; Myers, Davies, Evans, & Stygall, 2005). Given these contradictory findings, and the likelihood that the deleterious effects of personality on health accumulate over time, it may be that the general tendency to underreport is mitigated by objectively poorer health. In other words, dismissive individuals may underreport, but do so regarding a less healthy “baseline.”

sec.title: Attachment, Functional Impairment, and Health: Positive and Negative Affect as Mediators
sec.p: The second major focus of the current work was to evaluate whether PA and NA mediated attachment–health links. Consistent with prior work (Moskowitz et al., 2008; Pennebaker, 2000), NA and PA each independently predicted both symptoms reports and functional impairment. In addition, both NA and PA were associated with attachment dimensions in theoretically consistent ways (Consedine & Magai, 2003). Overall, our findings were consistent with the expectation that NA was a more likely mediator.

Adding PA to the regressions re-revealed the positive zero-order relationship between security and functional impairment. As greater PA typically predicts better self-reported health and functional ability (Benyamini, Idler, Leventhal, & Leventhal, 2000), our results suggest that links between security and functional impairment are masked by PA. Once the effect of PA is controlled, the tendency to report impairment becomes more evident.

As expected, the addition of NA to the regression models produced stronger effects, completely mediating links between fearful avoidance and both symptom reports and functional impairment, while leaving security–health links untouched. Interestingly, catastrophizing has been shown to mediate links between health care visits and fearful avoidance, but not other attachment dimensions (Ciechanowski et al., 2003). It may be that this negative cognitive bias functions to elicit increased support and care taking from others (Sullivan et al., 2001).

sec.title: Conclusions and Future Directions
sec.p: The observation that NA mediates attachment–health links for some attachment dimensions, but not others, lends itself to the question of whether individuals with different attachment profiles differ in their experience and expression of negative emotions (Consedine, et al., 2012). Although not assessed in the current report, prior work suggests that global NA scores may index distinct emotional profiles for each attachment dimension. Given that specific discrete emotions have distinct links to health (Consedine & Moskowitz, 2007; Dickerson, Kemeny, Aziz, Kim, & Fahey, 2004), attachment-related variation in the contributing constituents of global NA may be important. For example, prior work has found that security and dismissiveness predict less shame, whereas fearful avoidance correlates with greater shame sensitivity (Consedine & Magai, 2003). In turn, shame sensitivity has been linked to suboptimal immune functioning, whereas other constituents of NA, such as guilt, anger, and sadness, have not (Dickerson et al., 2004). Increased shame in fearful avoidance may specifically contribute to poorer overall health in these individuals. Similarly, anxiety appears to be greater among individuals high in fearful avoidance (Consedine & Magai, 2003) and has been linked to increased disability (de Beurs et al., 1999) and greater functional deficits in older adults (Mehta et al., 2007).

Finally, unmeasured differences in the expression of emotions may be partially responsible. Attachment is linked to anger management styles (Mikulincer & Florian, 1998), which have links to health outcomes (Haukkala, Konttinen, Laatikainen, Kawachi, & Uutela, 2010). Anger can be constructive and motivate problem solving, or destructive, serving to justify one’s own feelings or attribute blame (Tangney, Wagner, Hill-Barlow, Marschall, & Gramzow, 1996). More important, whereas destructive anger predicts poorer heart outcomes, constructive anger is associated with reduced CHD risk (Spielberger, Krasner, & Solomon, 1988). Insecure attachment has been shown to index greater destructive (and less functional) anger (Mikulincer & Florian, 1998). Controlling for NA in our models may be partialling out the variation associated with the less constructive regulatory profile characterizing fearful avoidance. Overall, future work should look at both specific emotions and their expression in order to clarify the active components of NA responsible for mediating attachment–health links.

Although our data are complex, they are clear in denoting links between attachment, trait affect, and health outcomes that are worth further investigation. Our data suggest that NA is a key mediator of attachment–health links although perhaps primarily for fearful avoidance. Differences in PA appear to be less relevant. To our knowledge, the present report is the first to test for affective mediation among a community-dwelling sample of older adults or to consider attachment’s links to functional impairment. Prior work has typically utilized university student (e.g., Wearden et al., 2005), or clinical (e.g., Maunder & Hunter, 2009) samples, the results of which may not readily generalize.

Functional impairment and greater symptomology lead to increased health care costs and reduced quality of life. As such, our findings have important clinical implications, both in terms of identifying those at risk and treating the underlying factors that appear to contribute to worse health outcomes. Specifically, as NA appears to mediate both symptom reports and functional impairment in adults high in fearful avoidance, targeting these individuals and treating NA may reduce symptomology and functional impairment in these individuals. Although not directly assessed, these findings also lend some support to the idea that valid assessment of self-reported health may be problematic among some individuals, notably those high in dismissiveness. Dismissive individuals appear to underreport both symptomology and functional impairment; however, limits in our data, specifically the lack of objective health measures, prevent the assessment of this theory.

It follows that although there are strengths, these data are not without their weaknesses. Most obviously, the lack of objective health measures limits the conclusions that we can draw, and future work should identify whether objective health varies as a function of attachment style or whether differences across attachment dimensions are restricted to self-reported outcomes. In addition, the cross-sectional design means it remains unclear whether attachment and affect causally contribute to outcome or whether the reverse is true. Although the longitudinal stability of attachment in later life (Zhang & Labouvie-Vief, 2004) suggests attachment styles are unlikely to result from worsening health, the possibility of confounds remains; prospective work is clearly needed. Ironically, the report is also limited by the unique nature of the sample and recruitment location. Despite their representative nature, they are a specific cohort and group and findings may not necessarily generalize to other populations.

In sum, the current study provides preliminary insight into the complex interplays among dispositional styles of relating, trait emotionality, and the perception and expression of illness symptoms and functional impairment among older adults. Given cohort-related differences in attachment and the fact that many Western societies are confronted with increased longevity and morbidity, future work detailing when and how attachment and affect predict health and health behavioral outcomes should be a key focus for social scientists.

ack.p: We gratefully acknowledge two anonymous reviewers for their helpful comments on earlier drafts.
